SUBSECTION.NAME: Mutable List Structure
SUBSECTION.TEXT:
The basic operations on pairsconspair, carhead, and cdrtailcan be used to construct list structure and to select parts from list structure, but they are incapable of modifying list structure. The same is true of the list operations we have used so far, such as append and list, since these can be defined in terms of conspair, carhead, and cdrtail. To modify list structures we need new operations.
Lists x: ((a b) c d) and y: (e f).
Lists list(list("a", "b"), "c", "d") and y: list("e", "f").
Effect of (set-car! x y) on the lists in figure.
Effect of set_head(x, y) on the lists in figure.
Effect of (define z (cons y (cdr x))) on the lists in figure.
Effect of const z = pair(y, tail(x)); on the lists in figure.
Effect of (set-cdr! x y) on the lists in figure.
Effect of set_tail(x, y) on the lists in figure.

The primitive mutators for pairs are set-car!set_head and set-cdr!set_tail. Set-car!The function set_head takes two arguments, the first of which must be a pair. It modifies this pair, replacing the carhead pointer by a pointer to the second argument of set-car!set_head. Set-car! and set-cdr!set_tail return implementation-dependent
unspecified valuesset-car@set-car!set_head
unspecified valuesset-cdr@set-cdr! values. Like set!assignment, they should be used only for their effect. The functions set_head and set_tail return the value undefined.
unspecified valuesset-head@set_head
unspecified valuesset-tail@set_tail Like assignment, they should be used only for their effect.

As an example, suppose that x is bound to the list ((a b) c d)list(list("a", "b"), "c") and y to the list (e f)list("e", "f") as illustrated in figure. Evaluating the expression (set-car! x y)set_head(x, y) modifies the pair to which x is bound, replacing its carhead by the value of y. The result of the operation is shown in figure. The structure x has been modified and would now be printed as ((ef)cd)list(list("e", "f"), "c", "d"). The pairs representing the list (a b)list("a", "b"), identified by the pointer that was replaced, are now detached from the original structure.We see from this that mutation operations on lists can create garbage that is not part of any accessible structure.
We will see in section that LispJavaScript memory-management systems include a garbage collectionmutation and garbage collector, which identifies and recycles the memory space used by unneeded pairs.

Compare figure with figure, which illustrates the result of executing
mutable_list_example
(define x '((a b) c d)) (define y '(e f))
const x = list(list("a", "b"), "c"); const y = list("e", "f");
mutable_list_example
(define z (cons y (cdr x)))
const z = pair(y, tail(x));
with x and y bound to the original lists of figure. The variable z is now bound to a new pair created by the conspair operation; the list to which x is bound is unchanged.

The set-cdr!set_tail operation is similar to set-car!set_head. The only difference is that the cdrtail pointer of the pair, rather than the carhead pointer, is replaced. The effect of executing (set-cdr! x y)set_tail(x, y) on the lists of figure is shown in figure. Here the cdrtail pointer of x has been replaced by the pointer to (e f)list("e", "f"). Also, the list (c d)list("c", "d"), which used to be the cdrtail of x, is now detached from the structure.
SUBSECTION.EXERCISE:
The following procedurefunction for appending lists was introduced in section:
append2
(define (append x y) (if (null? x) y (cons (car x) (append (cdr x) y))))
function append(x, y) { return is_null(x) ? y : pair(head(x), append(tail(x), y)); }
AppendThe function append forms a new list by successively conspairing the elements of x onto y. The procedurefunction append!append_mutator is similar to append, but it is a mutator rather than a constructor. It appends the lists by splicing them together, modifying the final pair of x so that its cdrtail is now y. (It is an error to call append!append_mutator with an emptyx.)
last_pair append_mutator
(define (append! x y) (set-cdr! (last-pair x) y) x)
function append_mutator(x, y) { set_tail(last_pair(x), y); }
Here last-pairlast_pair is a procedurefunction that returns the last pair in its argument:
last_pair
(define (last-pair x) (if (null? (cdr x)) x (last-pair (cdr x))))
function last_pair(x) { return is_null(tail(x))) ? x : last_pair(tail(x)); }
Consider the interaction program
append2 append_mutator
(define x (list 'a 'b)) (define y (list 'c 'd)) (define z (append x y)) z ;; (a b c d) (cdr x) ;; ??? (define w (append! x y)) w ;; (a b c d) (cdr x) ;; ???
const x = list("a", "b"); const y = list("c", "d"); const z = append(x, y); display(z); // ["a", ["b", ["c", ["d", null]]]] display(tail(x)); // ??? const w = append_mutator(x, y); display(w); // ["a", ["b", ["c", ["d", null]]]] display(tail(x)); // ???
^response^
What are the missing responses? Draw box-and-pointer diagrams to explain your answer.

cycle in list Consider the following make-cyclemake_cycle procedurefunction, which uses the last-pairlast_pair procedurefunction defined in exercise:
last_pair make_cycle
(define (make-cycle x) (set-cdr! (last-pair x) x) x)
function make_cycle(x) { set_tail(last_pair(x), x); return x; }
Draw a box-and-pointer diagram that shows the structure z created by
make_cycle
(define z (make-cycle (list 'a 'b 'c)))
const z = make_cycle(list("a", "b", "c"));
What happens if we try to compute (last-pair z)last_pair(z)?
SUBSECTION.TEXT:
sameness and changeshared data and change and samenessshared data and We mentioned in section the theoretical issues of sameness and change raised by the introduction of assignment. These issues arise in practice when individual pairs are shared among different data objects. For example, consider the structure formed by
pair_example1
(define x (list 'a 'b)) (define z1 (cons x x))
const x = list("a", "b"); const z1 = pair(x, x);

As shown in figure, z1 is a pair whose carhead and cdrtail both point to the same pair x. This sharing of x by the carhead and cdrtail of z1 is a consequence of the straightforward way in which conspair is implemented. In general, using conspair to construct lists will result in an interlinked structure of pairs in which many individual pairs are shared by many different structures.
The list z1 formed by (cons x x).
The list z1 formed by pair(x, x).
The list z2 formed by (cons (list 'a 'b) (list 'a 'b)).
The list z2 formed by pair(list("a", "b"), list("a", "b")).

In contrast to figure, figure shows the structure created by
pair_example2
(define z2 (cons (list 'a 'b) (list 'a 'b)))
const z2 = pair(list("a", "b"), list("a", "b"));

In this structure, the pairs in the two (a b)list("a", "b") lists are distinct, although
the actual symbols are shared. The two pairs are distinct because each call to cons returns a new pair. The symbols are shared; in Scheme there is a unique symbol with any given symbol(s)uniqueness of name. Since Scheme provides no way to mutate a symbol, this sharing is undetectable. Note also that the sharing is what enables us to compare symbols using eq?, which simply checks equality of pointers.
they contain the same strings. The two pairs are distinct because each call to pair returns a new pair. The strings are the same in the sense that they are primitive data (just like numbers) that are composed of the same characters in the same order. Since JavaScript provides no way to mutate a string, any sharing that the designers of a JavaScript interpreter might decide to implement for strings is undetectable. We consider primitive data such as numbers, booleans and strings as identical, if and only if they are indistinguishable.

When thought of as a list, z1 and z2 both represent the same list:
((a b) a b)
list(list("a", "b"), "a", "b")
In general, sharing is completely undetectable if we operate on lists using only conspair, carhead, and cdrtail. However, if we allow mutators on list structure, sharing becomes significant. As an example of the difference that sharing can make, consider the following procedurefunction, which modifies the carhead of the structure to which it is applied:
set_to_wow
(define (set-to-wow! x) (set-car! (car x) 'wow) x)
function set_to_wow(x) { set_head(head(x), "wow"); return x; }

One way to detect sharing in list structures is to use the predicate
eq?operator === , which we introduced in section as a way to test whether two symbolsstrings are equal. More generally,
(eq? x y) x === y tests whether x and y are the same object (that is, whether x and y are equal as pointers). Thus, with z1 and z2 as defined in figures and,
(eq? (carz1) (cdrz1)) head(z1) === tail(z1) is true and
(eq? (car z2) (cdr z2)) head(z2) === tail(z2) is false.

mutable data objectsshared data As will be seen in the following sections, we can exploit sharing to greatly extend the repertoire of data structures that can be represented by pairs. On the other hand, sharing can also be dangerous, since modifications made to structures will also affect other structures that happen to share the modified parts. The mutation operations set-car!set_head and set-cdr!set_tail should be used with care; unless we have a good understanding of how our data objects are shared, mutation can have unanticipated results.The subtleties of dealing with sharing of mutable data objects reflect the underlying issues of sameness and change that were raised in section. We mentioned there that admitting change to our language requires that a compound object must have an identity that is something different from the pieces from which it is composed. In LispJavaScript, we consider this identity to be the quality that is tested by eq?===, i.e., by equality of pointers. Since in most LispJavaScript implementations a pointer is essentially a memory address, we are solving the problem of defining the identity of objects by stipulating that a data object itself is the information stored in some particular set of memory locations in the computer. This suffices for simple LispJavaScript programs, but is hardly a general way to resolve the issue of sameness in computational models.
SUBSECTION.EXERCISE: Draw box-and-pointer diagrams to explain the effect of set-to-wow!set_to_wow on the structures z1 and z2 above.

Ben Bitdiddle decides to write a procedurefunction to count the number of pairs in any list structure. Its easy, he reasons. The number of pairs in any structure is the number in the carhead plus the number in the cdrtail plus one more to count the current pair. So Ben writes the following procedurefunction:
(define (count-pairs x) (if (not (pair? x)) 0 (+ (count-pairs (car x)) (count-pairs (cdr x)) 1)))
function count_pairs(x) { return !is_pair(x) ? 0 : count_pairs(head(x)) + count_pairs(tail(x)) + 1; }
Show that this procedurefunction is not correct. In particular, draw box-and-pointer diagrams representing list structures made up of exactly three pairs for which Bens procedurefunction would return 3; return 4; return 7; never return at all.

Devise a correct version of the count-pairscount_pairs procedurefunction of exercise that returns the number of distinct pairs in any structure. (Hint: Traverse the structure, maintaining an auxiliary data structure that is used to keep track of which pairs have already been counted.)

cycle in listdetecting Write a procedurefunction that examines a list and determines whether it contains a cycle, that is, whether a program that tried to find the end of the list by taking successive cdrtails would go into an infinite loop. Exercise constructed such lists.
Redo exercise using an algorithm that takes only a constant amount of space. (This requires a very clever idea.)
SUBSECTION.TEXT: Assignment is all that is needed, theoretically, to account for the behavior of mutable data. As soon as we admit set!assignment to our language, we raise all the issues, not only of assignment, but of mutable data in general.On the other hand, from the viewpoint of implementation, assignment requires us to modify the environment, which is itself a mutable data structure. Thus, assignment and mutation are equipotent: Each can be implemented in terms of the other.
SUBSECTION.EXERCISE:
Draw environment diagrams to illustrate the evaluation of the sequence of expressions
pair2
(define x (cons 1 2)) (define z (cons x x)) (set-car! (cdr z) 17)
(car x)
const x = pair(1, 2); const z = pair(x, x); set_head(tail(z), 17); head(x);
17
using the
procedural
functional
implementation of pairs given above. (Compare exercise.)
